metadata.case_name: State of Maharashtra & Anr. v. Mayor of Nagpur Municipal Corporation & Ors.

facts.text: Term of office of present Councillors commenced in July 1962.
Government of Maharashtra issued show-cause notice dated July 21, 1965 to respondent No. 1 (Mayor) asking why Corporation should not be superseded.
Respondent No. 1 filed reply to show-cause notice on August 1, 1965.
State Government passed order dated September 29, 1965 superseding Corporation under ss. 408 and 409 of City of Nagpur Corporation Act 1948.
Respondent No. 1 filed writ petition on September 30, 1965 challenging show-cause notice and supersession order.
Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench allowed writ petition by judgment dated October 7, 1966, quashed supersession order holding grounds not reasonably related and finding rationally impossible.
Free cash balance in March 1962: Rs. 5.81 lacs; on July 12, 1965: Rs. 53,821. Budget receipts vs actual: 1963-64 (351 vs 173 lacs), 1964-65 (221 vs 190 lacs), 1965-66 anticipated 200-215 lacs.
Corporation passed Resolution No. 98 dated September 4, 1965 resolving to raise loan of Rs. 15 lacs from State Government.
Water supply inadequate due to increasing population; improvement needed at Kanhan Stage III (ad hoc loan Rs. 21 lacs sanctioned in 1964) and remodelling distribution system (estimated Rs. 70 lacs).
Standing Committee resolved on June 5, 1965 to raise Rs. 70 lacs loan accepting universal meterisation and separate water budget.
Corporation at meeting on June 30, 1965 disapproved Standing Committee's resolution on universal meterisation and separate budget (no specific resolution passed).
Meeting convened July 5, 1965 adjourned; agenda noted Government's conditions: immediate meterisation and separate water budget.
Corporation passed resolution on July 12, 1965 approving Rs. 70 lacs loan (Rs. 24 lacs Kanhan III, Rs. 45 lacs distribution) and directing action for State guarantee, without mentioning conditions.
Corporation paid salaries but not dearness allowance due to unscrutinized bills.
Cost of immediate meterisation of old connections estimated at Rs. 52 lacs by Corporation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the State Government's order superseding the Nagpur Municipal Corporation under s. 408 was valid, particularly if based on grounds where no reasonable person could form the required opinion, or without opportunity, or in bad faith.
Whether the order is vitiated if based on multiple grounds, some irrelevant or non-existent.

petitioner_arguments.text: First ground (financial mismanagement, cash balance deterioration, no funds for salaries) invalid as no opportunity given on specific charges like uncertain receipts or lack of controls; cash balances fluctuate; salaries paid; resolution post-notice; statement A factually incorrect.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 408 City of Nagpur Corporation Act 1948

petitioner_arguments.text: Second ground (neglect of water supply improvement) invalid as Corporation approved Rs. 70 lacs loan on July 12, leaving conditions for negotiation; meterisation costs Rs. 52 lacs impossible without additional loan.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 408, s.57(1)(k), s.90 City of Nagpur Corporation Act 1948

petitioner_arguments.text: Order invalid as based on two grounds, one non-existent/irrelevant, per preventive detention principles.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dwarka Dass Bhatia v. State of J&K

respondent_arguments.text: Corporation planned expenditure on uncertain receipts without proper controls, leading to financial crisis; no funds for salaries evident from resolution.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 47,49,50 City of Nagpur Corporation Act 1948

respondent_arguments.text: Corporation neglected water supply duties by refusing Government's reasonable conditions (universal meterisation, separate budget) for loan guarantee, making loan impossible; July 12 resolution virtually rejected conditions.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 57(1)(k), s.408 City of Nagpur Corporation Act 1948

respondent_arguments.text: Even if first ground invalid, second ground sufficient; show-cause notice stated grounds jointly and severally serious; would have acted on second alone.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of Orissa v. Bidyabhushan Mahapatra; Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. CIT

court_reasoning.text: Power under s.408 exercised if Corporation incompetent, defaults persistently, or abuses powers; must give opportunity except emergency; court examines if no reasonable person could form opinion on materials, or bad faith, or no opportunity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No appeal; court does not review facts as appellate body but checks excess of power.

court_reasoning.text: First ground invalid: no opportunity on specific charges; cash balances vary; salaries paid; resolution post-notice; no reasonable opinion possible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court correct on first ground.

court_reasoning.text: Second ground valid: Corporation effectively rejected conditions by resolutions; conditions reasonable for revenue and fund allocation; no mention of Rs.52 lacs need in reply or resolution; materials support neglect of water duty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State could form opinion of incompetence.

court_reasoning.text: Order not vitiated by one invalid ground if remaining relevant ground sufficient and would have led to same decision; notice said grounds jointly/severally serious; second ground alone warranted action.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes preventive detention cases; applies administrative order principles.

holdings.text: Supersession order valid under s.408 as based on valid second ground of neglect in water supply duties, sufficient for opinion of incompetence.
Administrative order with multiple grounds sustained if relevant grounds alone would suffice and exclusion of invalid ones would not affect decision.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Committee, Karari v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Construction of ss.53A,57 C.P. Berar Municipalities Act 1922 on quasi-judicial nature.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Radheshyam Khare v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Construction of ss.53A,57 C.P. Berar Municipalities Act 1922.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarka Dass Bhatia v. State of Jammu and Kashmir
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle for subjective satisfaction orders like preventive detention: invalid if based on non-existent/irrelevant grounds affecting satisfaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maursinha v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Supersession order invalid if most grounds irrelevant.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Finding vitiated if partly relevant/irrelevant material used.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Orissa v. Bidyabhushan Mahapatra
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissal order upheld if supported by any substantial finding even if some invalid.

statutes_cited.name: City of Nagpur Corporation Act, 1948 (C.P. Berar Act II of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs supersession for incompetence/default/abuse; water supply duties; salaries as charge on fund; loan powers.

statutes_cited.name: C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922 (Act II of 1922)
statutes_cited.relevance: Distinguished on quasi-judicial nature of similar supersession powers.

statutes_cited.name: City of Nagpur Corporation Loans Rules, 1951

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order quashing supersession, upheld State Government's order of September 29, 1965 superseding Nagpur Municipal Corporation as valid under s.408 based on second ground alone.

key_quotes.text: "the order is liable to be set aside if no reasonable person on a proper consideration of the materials before the State government could form the opinion that the Corporation is not competent to perform, or persistently makes default..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of judicial review of s.408 order.

key_quotes.text: "An administrative or quasi-judicial order based on several grounds... cannot be sustained if... some of the grounds are non-existent or irrelevant, and there is nothing to show that the authority would have passed the order on the basis of the other relevant..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle applied to uphold order on remaining valid ground.

key_quotes.text: "the grounds aforesaid jointly as well as severally appear serious enough to warrant action under section 408(1)"
key_quotes.speaker: prosecution
key_quotes.significance: From show-cause notice, supports sufficiency of individual grounds.
